calculationType.citation: Page 8, late charge provision – “2% of the monthly payment will be assessed as a late charge.”

secondFeeCalculationType.citation: Page 21 – “late charge in an amount equal to five percent (5%) of such payment.”

secondFeeGrace.citation: Page 21 – no grace period mentioned for the 5% charge

synopsis.value: The Premises are located at 5100 W. J.B. Hunt Drive, Suite 602, Rogers, Arkansas 72758 on the 6th floor, consisting of approximately 12,824 usable square feet and 14,952 rentable square feet. The Primary Term ends on the last day of the 77th full month, with an option to extend to 90 months.

amendments.previous_value: approximately 14,642 usable square feet and 17,090 rentable square feet
amendments.new_value: approximately 12,824 usable square feet and 14,952 rentable square feet
amendments.description: Premises size reduced per Second Lease Amendment.

keyParameters.value: Usable Area: 12,824 sf; Rentable Area: 14,952 sf; Building Total Rentable: 226,468 sf; Primary Term: 77 months; Extension Option: up to 90 months; Rent Commencement: 6th full month (or 7th if extended)

amendments.previous_value: Usable Area: 14,642 sf; Rentable Area: 17,090 sf
amendments.new_value: Usable Area: 12,824 sf; Rentable Area: 14,952 sf

narrative.value: As indicated by the area on Exhibit A attached to the Lease, situated on the 6th floor in the building commonly known as PH Office 2, LLC (the "Building") located at 5100 W. J.B. Hunt Drive, Suite 602, Rogers, Arkansas 72758. The Premises consists of approximately Twelve Thousand Eight Hundred Twenty‑four (12,824) usable square feet and Fourteen Thousand Nine Hundred Fifty‑two (14,952) rentable square feet. Primary Term shall end on the last day of the seventy‑seventh (77th) full month. Tenant may extend the term to ninety (90) months within fourteen (14) days of the Commencement Date (later restated as twenty‑one (21) days). Rent Commences on the first day of the sixth (6th) full month of the Primary Term (or the seventh (7th) full month if the extension is exercised).

amendments.previous_value: Fourteen Thousand Six Hundred Forty‑two (14,642) usable square feet and Seventeen Thousand Ninety (17,090) rentable square feet
amendments.new_value: Twelve Thousand Eight Hundred Twenty‑four (12,824) usable square feet and Fourteen Thousand Nine Hundred Fifty‑two (14,952) rentable square feet
amendments.description: Narrative updated to reflect downsized premises.

synopsis.value: Landlord pays real property taxes; any amount exceeding the Base Year (calendar year 2016) is passed through to Tenant on a pro‑ra ta basis. Tenant is responsible for taxes on personal property and fixtures.

definition.value: "Taxes" means real property taxes and special assessments on the Premises, Land and improvements, and personal property taxes on Tenant’s fixtures.

keyParameters.value: Base Year: 2016; Pass‑through threshold: any tax amount exceeding Base Year; Tenant liability for personal property taxes.

narrative.value: Landlord agrees to pay all real property taxes and special assessments that accrue against the Premises, and/or the Land and/or improvements of which the Premises are a part. Property taxes incurred in any year during the lease term which exceed the taxes on the property during the "Base Year" (2016) will be passed through to building tenants based on a pro‑ra ta square footage basis. Tenant shall be liable for all taxes levied or assessed against any personal property or fixtures placed in the Premises.

synopsis.value: Operating expenses in excess of the Base Year (2022) are passed through to Tenant on a pro‑ra ta basis. Tenant pays its share as Additional Rent monthly, with annual reconciliation.

amendments.previous_value: Operating expenses in excess of the Base Year (2016) are passed through to Tenant on a pro‑ra ta basis.
amendments.new_value: Operating expenses in excess of the Base Year (2022) are passed through to Tenant on a pro‑ra ta basis.
amendments.description: Base Year for Operating Expenses changed from 2016 to 2022 per Section 4 of the amendment.

definition.value: "Operating Expenses" means the actual ordinary and reasonable costs and expenses incurred by Landlord for ownership, management, maintenance, repair, replacement, restoration or operation of the Real Property, excluding capital improvements, casualty repairs, financing costs, depreciation, leasing commissions, legal fees, and other excluded items.

keyParameters.value: Base Year: 2022; Pass‑through threshold: expenses exceeding Base Year; Tenant Share: proportional to rentable square footage; Controllable expense cap: 5% annual increase.

amendments.previous_value: Base Year: 2016; Pass‑through threshold: expenses exceeding Base Year; Tenant Share: proportional to rentable square footage; Controllable expense cap: 5% annual increase.
amendments.new_value: Base Year: 2022; Pass‑through threshold: expenses exceeding Base Year; Tenant Share: proportional to rentable square footage; Controllable expense cap: 5% annual increase.

billingTimeline.value: Landlord provides an annual statement within ninety (90) days after year‑end; Tenant pays monthly Additional Rent based on estimated increase; any over‑payment or under‑payment reconciled within thirty (30) days of receipt of the Annual Statement.

formulas.value: Tenant's Proportionate Share = (Tenant Rentable Sq Ft ÷ Building Total Rentable Sq Ft) × 100%; Additional Rent = Tenant's Share × (Operating Expenses – Base Year Expenses).

amendments.previous_value: Tenant's Proportionate Share = (Tenant Rentable Sq Ft ÷ Building Total Rentable Sq Ft) × 100%; Additional Rent = Tenant's Share × (Operating Expenses – Base Year Expenses).
amendments.new_value: Tenant's Proportionate Share = (Tenant Rentable Sq Ft ÷ Building Total Rentable Sq Ft) × 100%; Additional Rent = Tenant's Share × (Operating Expenses – Base Year Expenses).
amendments.description: Proportionate share percentage updated to 6.6% (see amendment).

capitalRules.value: Capital improvements are excluded from Operating Expenses unless they directly reduce Tenant's Operating Expenses; such costs are amortized on a straight‑line basis over their useful life. Tenant‑caused capital improvements are amortized over the remainder of the lease term.

narrative.value: Operating expenses (as defined herein) incurred in any year during the lease term which exceed the operating expenses on the Building for the Base Year (2022) will be passed through to the Building tenants on a prorata basis. Operating Expenses shall be adjusted to reflect the Operating ... Controllable Operating Expenses shall not increase by more than five percent (5%) annually following Tenant's Base Year. Landlord shall send to Tenant a written statement of the amount of Tenant's Proportionate Share of any estimated increase in Operating Expenses and Tenant shall pay to Landlord, monthly as Additional Rent, Tenant's prorata share of such increase in Operating Expenses. Within ninety (90) days after the end of each calendar year, Landlord shall send an annual statement of Operating Expenses ...

synopsis.value: Tenant shall be entitled to seventy‑five (75) parking spaces as a result of the reduction of the Premises.

amendments.previous_value: Tenant is entitled to not less than 4.5 parking spaces per 1,000 rentable square feet at no charge. No exclusive reserved spaces are provided to Tenant.
amendments.new_value: Tenant shall be entitled to seventy‑five (75) parking spaces as a result of the reduction of the Premises.
amendments.description: Parking allocation increased to 75 spaces per amendment Section 16.

executiveSummary.value: This lease, dated May 2015, is between PH Office 2, LLC (Landlord) and Bayer HealthCare LLC (Tenant). The Premises are on the 6th floor of 5100 W.J.B. Hunt Drive, Suite 602, Rogers, Arkansas, comprising approximately 14,952 rentable square feet (12,824 usable square feet) after a downsizing amendment effective February 1 2022. The Primary Term runs for 77 months, ending on the last day of the 77th full month, with a Tenant‑option to extend to 90 months by giving notice within 21 days of Commencement; two additional five‑year Renewal Terms are available upon 180‑365 day notice. Base rent is set per the amendment table (Year 1 $33,019 annual, $396,228 monthly, etc.) and is calculated on the reduced rentable area. Tenant receives a one‑time early termination right after 36 months of occupancy and is allocated 75 parking spaces. Operating Expenses Base Year changed to 2022 and Tenant’s proportionate share is 6.6%.
executiveSummary.citation: Compiled from original lease and Second Lease Amendment (pages 1‑5)

audit_items.issue_description: Lease Date is shown as "_`--5. 2015" which is garbled and unclear.
audit_items.recommended_action: Confirm the exact lease execution date with the parties and update the record.

audit_items.issue_description: Security Deposit field is marked as "Intentionally Deleted" with no amount provided.
audit_items.affected_clause: Security Deposit (Section 2 – Base Rent and Security Deposit)
audit_items.recommended_action: Obtain the intended security deposit amount or confirm that no deposit is required.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit A, B, C, D, and E are placeholders with no substantive data (e.g., rentable square footage, tenant improvements, rules, memorandum details).
audit_items.affected_clause: References to Exhibits throughout the lease (e.g., Premises description, Tenant Improvements, Rules and Regulations, Memorandum of Acceptance).
audit_items.recommended_action: Secure the finalized exhibits and attach them to the lease file.

audit_items.issue_description: Primary Term extension notice is 14 days in Section 3 (page 3) but 21 days in Section 5 (page 5).
audit_items.affected_clause: Extension of Primary Term notice period
audit_items.recommended_action: Clarify and reconcile the correct notice period for lease extension.

audit_items.issue_description: Rent Commencement is described as the first day of the 6th full month (page 3) but also states rent commences on the first day of the 7th full month if the tenant extends to 90 months (page 3).
audit_items.recommended_action: Specify a single, unambiguous rent commencement rule for both scenarios.

audit_items.issue_description: Commencement Date depends on multiple conditions (Landlord’s substantial completion, notice, tenant’s 2‑day furniture installation window, certificate of occupancy) without clear sequencing or deadlines.
audit_items.recommended_action: Create a detailed timeline with explicit dates or maximum allowable delays for each condition.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant Improvements must be performed in a "good and workmanlike manner" and comply with all applicable laws, but no objective criteria are defined for "good and workmanlike".
audit_items.recommended_action: Define measurable standards or reference industry guidelines for workmanship quality.

audit_items.category: Subjective Standard – Reasonable and Good‑Faith Determination
audit_items.issue_description: Landlord must provide a "reasonable and good‑faith determination" of the annual Base Rent for Renewal Terms (page 5). No criteria are provided.
audit_items.recommended_action: Specify the methodology, benchmarks, or third‑party data to be used for this determination.

audit_items.category: Unquantified Financial Risk – Tenant Improvement Allowance
audit_items.issue_description: Improvement Allowance is stated as $72.22 per rentable square foot (page 6) but the total dollar amount ($1,234,239.80) may not align with the actual rentable area (17,090 RSF) and no cap is mentioned for overruns.
audit_items.recommended_action: Re‑calculate the total allowance based on the exact rentable square footage and include an overruns cap or cost‑sharing mechanism.

audit_items.category: Unquantified Financial Risk – Early Termination Fee
audit_items.issue_description: Early termination fee includes reimbursement of the unamortized Improvement Allowance and Broker's commission, amortized with 7% annual interest, but the exact formula and timing are not detailed.
audit_items.recommended_action: Provide a clear amortization schedule and define the date of interest calculation.

audit_items.category: Ambiguous Cost Allocation – Operating Expenses Cap
audit_items.issue_description: Controllable Operating Expenses shall not increase by more than 5% annually (page 9) but the definition of "controllable" excludes taxes and insurance, creating potential disputes over classification.
audit_items.recommended_action: List specific expense categories considered controllable and provide examples.

audit_items.issue_description: Basic Lease Information states it controls over conflicts (page 4), yet later sections (e.g., Section 29 – Notices) may contain contradictory language without reference to Basic Lease Information.
audit_items.recommended_action: Insert a definitive clause stating the hierarchy and ensure all sections reference it consistently.

audit_items.issue_description: Base Rent schedule appears twice (pages 8 and 9) with identical figures, increasing the risk of inconsistency if one copy is edited.
audit_items.recommended_action: Consolidate the table into a single reference and cross‑link any future updates.

audit_items.category: Missing Critical Field – Tenant’s Proportionate Share
audit_items.issue_description: Tenant’s Proportionate Share percentage is left blank in Exhibit D (page 38).
audit_items.recommended_action: Calculate and insert the correct proportion based on rentable square footage.

audit_items.category: Conditional Clause – First Right of Refusal
audit_items.issue_description: First Right of Refusal (Section 30, page 27) requires tenant to notify within 10 business days, but the notice period for the landlord to present the offer is not defined.
audit_items.recommended_action: Specify the landlord’s notice deadline and method of communication.

audit_items.category: Ambiguous Term – "Reasonable" Costs for Additional Services
audit_items.issue_description: Janitorial services may be arranged at "reasonable rates" (page 13) without a defined benchmark.
audit_items.recommended_action: Define a pricing formula or reference market rates.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant may request qualified maintenance personnel; Landlord must provide them without charge, but “qualified” is undefined (page 11).
audit_items.recommended_action: Establish qualification criteria (certifications, experience) for maintenance staff.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant is liable for cleanup costs of hazardous material spills, but no cap or insurance requirement is stated (page 24).
audit_items.recommended_action: Require Tenant to maintain environmental liability insurance and set a maximum exposure limit.

audit_items.issue_description: Force Majeure Delays are referenced in multiple sections (e.g., lease termination after 120 days) without a definition of what constitutes such delays (page 15).
audit_items.recommended_action: Insert a definition listing specific events that qualify as force majeure.

audit_items.category: Missing Financial Detail – Late Charge Rate
audit_items.issue_description: Late charge is described as 5% of the overdue amount (page 21) but the lease also mentions a 2% late charge elsewhere (page 8), creating inconsistency.
audit_items.recommended_action: Standardize the late charge rate throughout the lease.

audit_items.category: Conflicting Termination Rights – Landlord vs. Tenant
audit_items.issue_description: Landlord may terminate for insurance shortfall (Section 15(D), page 15) while Tenant also has a termination right after 120 days of unrepaired damage (Section 15(B), page 15). Overlap may cause disputes.
audit_items.recommended_action: Clarify the order of precedence and conditions for each termination right.

audit_items.issue_description: Premises size to be measured by Core Architects and validated by Nielsen Architects using ANSI/BOMA Z65.1‑1996, but no deadline for completion is set.
audit_items.recommended_action: Add a specific timeline for measurement and validation, and define consequences for delays.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant’s responsibility for insurance deductibles is not specified, though Tenant must maintain policies (page 14).
audit_items.recommended_action: Insert a clause allocating deductible costs to either Landlord or Tenant.

audit_items.category: Subjective Standard – "Reasonable" Adjustments to Base Rent
audit_items.issue_description: Landlord must provide a “reasonable and good‑faith determination” of annual Base Rent for Renewal Terms (page 5), but no formula is provided.
audit_items.recommended_action: Adopt a market rent survey method or index to calculate renewal rent.

audit_items.issue_description: Section 5 defines “walls” as not including components of Tenant Improvements, yet earlier sections assign repair obligations to Tenant for walls (page 11).
audit_items.recommended_action: Clarify which walls are tenant‑responsible versus landlord‑responsible.

audit_items.issue_description: Broker commission amount is not disclosed anywhere; only broker names are listed (page 4).
audit_items.recommended_action: Obtain the agreed commission percentage or dollar amount and document it.

audit_items.issue_description: Holding over rent is set at 150% of monthly rent plus operating expenses (page 18) but the calculation method for partial months is vague.
audit_items.recommended_action: Specify prorated rent calculation for partial days.

audit_items.category: Ambiguous Term – "Reasonable" Access Hours for Moving
audit_items.issue_description: Moving hours are limited to 7:00 am‑6:00 pm (page 36) but no exception process is defined for emergencies or special circumstances.
audit_items.recommended_action: Create a request procedure for after‑hours moves.

audit_items.issue_description: Landlord’s consent to sublease is deemed given if no response within ten business days (page 15), but no method of notice is defined.
audit_items.recommended_action: Define the acceptable method of delivering the sublease request (e.g., certified mail, email).

audit_items.issue_description: Landlord may discontinue extra services after 30 days of non‑payment and treat them as additional rent (page 14), but no cap on such charges is provided.
audit_items.recommended_action: Set a maximum percentage or dollar limit for additional service charges.

audit_items.category: Ambiguous Term – "Reasonable" Cost for Third Appraiser
audit_items.issue_description: If two appraisers cannot agree, a third is appointed; costs are split but “reasonable” cost is not defined (page 5).
audit_items.recommended_action: Specify a fee schedule or maximum cost for the third appraiser.

audit_items.category: Missing Financial Detail – Late Charge Interest Rate
audit_items.issue_description: Late charge is 5% of overdue amount (page 21) but earlier mention of a 2% late charge exists (page 8), creating inconsistency.
audit_items.recommended_action: Consolidate to a single late charge rate and delete the contradictory provision.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant may use qualified maintenance personnel at no charge (page 11), but “qualified” and “no charge” are not defined.
audit_items.recommended_action: Define qualifications and confirm that costs (e.g., parts, overtime) are covered.

audit_items.category: Ambiguous Term – "Reasonable" Use of Building Name
audit_items.issue_description: Tenant may use the building name only in a conventional manner (page 26), but “conventional” is not defined.
audit_items.recommended_action: Provide examples or a style guide for permissible usage.

audit_items.category: Missing Clause – Insurance Cancellation Notice Period
audit_items.issue_description: Policies shall not be canceled unless 30 days prior written notice is given (page 14), but no procedure for providing such notice is described.
audit_items.recommended_action: Add a notice method (e.g., certified mail) and address requirement.

audit_items.issue_description: Operating Expenses exclude capital improvements (page 9) but later Section 4 lists capital improvements as excluded only if they reduce Tenant’s expenses, creating potential overlap.
audit_items.recommended_action: Provide a clear, exhaustive list of excluded items.

audit_items.category: Missing Financial Detail – Broker Commission for Reletting
audit_items.issue_description: Landlord may recover broker’s commission in default remedies (page 21) but the commission amount or percentage is not specified.
audit_items.recommended_action: Insert the agreed broker commission rate or a method to calculate it.

audit_items.category: Ambiguous Term – "Reasonable" Cost for Additional Rent
audit_items.issue_description: Additional Rent for Operating Expenses is payable monthly, but “reasonable” cost for services like extra temperature control is not defined (page 13).
audit_items.recommended_action: Reference market rates or provide a cost schedule.

audit_items.issue_description: Section 22 mentions subordination to mortgages but does not include a non‑disturbance clause, which is critical for tenant protection.
audit_items.recommended_action: Add a standard non‑disturbance, non‑derogation clause.

audit_items.category: Ambiguous Term – "Reasonable" Time for Landlord to Cure Default
audit_items.issue_description: Landlord has 30 days to cure defaults (Section 33, page 28) but “reasonable diligence” is also mentioned elsewhere without a specific timeframe.
audit_items.recommended_action: Standardize cure periods and remove vague language.
